It’s a very charming show that highlights a more joyful side to the “killing game” trope. It was niceto see a fun twist placed on a trope with such a negative connotation. 


Seeing characters interacting with each other through such an unorthodox method is enjoyable especially when you see relationships develop especially with Koro-sensei. Though its character development is phenomenal I do think they could have done a little better with the soundtrack to me it’s kind of felt a bit left in the back ground in some scenes. It was there but it could have been fantastic same said about the closing songs. Other than that, the openings are great they really help convey the tone of the anime with a fun vibe. 


Art wise the style threw me off at first mainly because of the train of thought of ‘A killing game where characters look like that?’. Though further into the show I begun to love it. I liked the way the art style looked so simple and cute but still worked to portray the more intense scenes. The style really kept me feeling the innocence of high school life in amidst the sea of abnormality that was Koro-sensei, so I think it works well with the narrative. 


My suggestion to most people would be to give this anime an honest go, it has amazing character development, nice art style and a beautiful over arcing narrative that really ties the story together fantastically if you can stick it out to the end.

Ansatsu Kyoushitsu amazed me. Was it a good anime??...YES. Here is what i thought:
During the initial epidodes, i thought this anime is going to be a mess and we wont get much character development for all characters....but 90% of the students got a moment to shine. Koro sensei, Nagisa, Karma stood out...but when a character came up, you knew who it was.
Things i liked: 
Animation style, music and story was great. It was something new to experience. Plot twists were great and unexpected.
Things i disliked:
Some things bugged me, but it may not be an issue to you. Koro sensei's voice did not match his personality.I can't disclose some issues due to spoilers. Overall....a must watch anime.

I watched some of this like a year ago but dropped it because the episodic formula wasn't really working for me at the time. Then I picked it up again on a whim and finished it in two days. I now completely understand why it is so popular.
Story 10/10: The premise itself is pretty unique and enough to pique one's interest, but the way it unfolds is really what keeps you watching, although most of the intrigue doesn't get resolved this season. It's mostly episodic and definitely not as serious as you'd expect it to be based on the premise, apart from the very lastfew episodes, but this enables it to properly develop a lot of the characters and even if it doesn't really focus on the overarching story most of the time, it still manages to get across some quite meaningful messages about school and education and human relationships.


Art 10/10: It took me so long to get used to the character designs, I'm not even sure why, because they look good, very colourful and nice to look at, just quite peculiar. Other than that there's nothing to complain about, the movement is smooth, the backgrounds are beautiful, and sometimes, especially in the last few episodes, some scenes look mindblowingly good.


Sound 10/10: I'm not the biggest fan of the opening or ending themes, but the voice acting is incredible, with a very large number of standout performances from the main and secondary cast alike (special shoutout to Jun Fukuyama for being amazing). The ost is pretty great, with a lot of different instruments used in a large variety of tracks to fit all sorts of situations the characters find themselves in, tracks ranging from upbeat and funny to more quiet and subdued to mysterious and ominous.


Character 10/10: Not all characters get equal amounts of screen-time, but the ones who get some focus are very well-developed, they all have their own stories and motivations and personalities, and are very very easy to differentiate from the others, and there is tangible character development for some through the show. Interestingly enough, although Koro-sensei is undoubtedly a main character, he remains probably the most mysterious character in the anime, as we don't really know much about him, where he came from, who he really is, what his motivations are, nothing. So I'm looking forward to seeing more of him. Apart from that, my favourite character was Karma, but I did manage to get attached to most of the prominent characters. As for the antagonists, because they do exist, well... In my humble opinion this show has some of the best and most terrifying antagonists I've ever encountered.


Enjoyment 9.5/10: I decided to dock half a point just because I believe this is a show that you have to be in a particular mood in to really enjoy, as the first time I watched the first few episodes I found myself bored, however when I checked it out again I ended up binge-watching the entire thing. I even went back and rewatched the first few episodes and it's quite amazing how much my perspective has  changed on them.


Overall 10/10: I think your enjoyment of this show very much depends on your expectations and your sense of humour. I would not recommend going into this with many preconceived expectations, and I would definitely urge you to stay away if you're looking for something that takes itself seriously. However, if you're just looking for something fun and humorous with a great cast of characters, this is absolutely worth a watch.

Watched this one on a whim and was really blown away by how good it is. Episodic shows tend to not be my thing I really like over arching plots and narratives. This is surprising able to handle that while giving us fantastic development of everyone in class 3-E and is generally a really warm show to watch. Every time the class thinks they got Koro-sensei he's usually 3 steps ahead but will always commend them for their effort and ingenuity and pushes them further and further. Just a really solid show and doesn't do anything that makes me turn my nose up at it.Ritsu best girl btw and highly recommend the dub.

I love this anime, because is great and balanced mix of many things.
The story is really captivating and manages to capture you from the beginning to the end.
Korosensei aka 'the yellow octopus' is the best teacher of all time, he's really funny and takes care of every student without making preferences.
I like each student of the 'class E', because each of them is 'special'.
The 'class E' seems an old Japanese country school, placed in a green little valley, where students and teacher can be happy together.
I like the fact that the students in the first understood, that only as 'a team' they will be ableto kill their target, Korosensei.\n
Art and music are really nice.

The first season of Assassinaton Classroom is a hit. The premise, the worst students at a prestigious middle school are giving the task of killing their octopus teacher who can move at Mach 20. E-Class is severely segregated against at the main class. As Karasuma (the government black suit who's the P.E. teacher) so elegantly says in Episode 2 "The system's given up on these kids."
The story's simple enough. I'll take points off for playing their most cool-and-creative assassination attempts from individual students in the first three episodes. Korosensei is an absolute joy to listen to as he teaches the kids for life.
For most part,you have a large amount of students, and while most get their focus in the first season (some won't until Season 2), you're going to be dealing with three boy-girl pairs. Nagisa and Kaede (the male and females leads), Karma and Okuda (who doesn't show up until Episode 3 and the sciency-girl), and Sugino and Kanzaki (the baseball guy and class's gamer pretty girl). (When students are group into smaller subgroups, you'll often see these six together. 


The idea is that each character has enough substance and backstory and motivation that in most other settings they'd be the main character if Karma and Nagisa weren't upstaging them. Nagisa, himself is the epitome of the fact that an anime is only as strong as its main character. And Karma's a devilishly genius.


I have two problems One comes from the school side. I'm not Japanese, so I'm missing some context here. I get that. The principal is determined to keep 'E Class' in their place as the lowest students in the school. However, you would think that the principal would realize that having to RIG THE SYSTEM in order to keep E Class 'Down' means the system is broken. But wouldn't having an E Class do really well reflect very highly on the school? Hey, even our WORST Students are academic gems. Now imagine what are our best can do? 


My second problem is that nobody seems to improvise or be able to macguvyer an additional attack. For instance, in Episode 3, Karma starts getting in some great shots that are far more effective. You'd think someone would take advantage of the fact that Korosensei is exclusively focused on Karma at that point to get into their own shots.


EPISODE 3 EXAMPLE:

Karma throws himself off the back end of the cliff with a gun pointed up. The goal is to put Korosensei in an impossible situation, either he lets Karma die or he moves slow enough for Karma to shoot him. Korosensei manages to avoid either option by becoming a trampoline/spider web thing. That's all fine and good, Korosensei is tied up with holding Karma up in trees. Here's where I see a problem. Nagisa is there. Nagisa is watching. Why doesn't he jump over the cliff with a knife? Karma's stuck to Korosensei at that point, can't be detached. And Korosensei can't move because of Karma.  Korosensei is a sitting duck.

If my teacher asking me an anime to watch, I will put this anime at the number 1! This anime MUST be watched by all teachers in the universe!!
+Story+
10/10
Each episodes seem not boring, and I'm enjoying all of them. More fun, more adventure, more assassination. The anime turns funny to serious, and serious to funny at the right times.
The story is also showing what most students in our world want their teachers to know. While the elites discriminate them by their rank, they're focus to 'assassinate' their teacher.
However, the ending is a bit confusing. They should, or MUST make the second season so the animewatchers wouldn't get too confused for the story.


+Art+

8/10


The art style of the characters has a lining. It reminds me to Coppelion.


+Sound+

9/10


+Character+

10/10


They seems developing the characters very well.


+Enjoyment+

10/10


+Overall+

10/10

The Video Review is up on my channel, but here is the written.
Story - 7/10
The moon has been blown up, carved into a permanent crescent shape, and that same catastrophe is going to happen a year later on Earth. And it’s a tentacle monster that’s responsible for this. But for whatever reason, he gives humanity a chance to save themselves, that condition is, to allow him to teach at Kunugigaoka Junior High School, the class of 3-E, also known as the Dead End class. This class is considered to have no future and everyone neglects them, except for their new teacher. The government has giventhis class a task to eliminate their teacher and save the Earth. So it’s a conundrum that the students have to kill this teacher of theirs in order to gain themselves 10 billion yen, aka 100 million dollars, yet he is the best teacher they ever had.


Now obviously if the main plot is about killing their one and only teacher, you’re probably already know how every episode is going to turn out. Plus there is a season 2 in the works. Each episode usually focuses on a student in particular and their own personal assassination attempt. So it’s no surprise when all these assassination attempts fail, because you can’t kill off the plot device, otherwise there’ll be no series. The first half of the series is more of an introduction to all the characters in the show, whereas the second half has some more arcs related scenarios. You know each assassination attempt is going to fail, but what we learn from those fails are life lessons, so to speak. However the plot does have a repetitive narrative, so I loved that the last arc was something different and fresh for series, turning it from episodic to an adventure arc. 


Characters - 7/10


As for our plot device we have Korosensei as named by his students. Also his name literally means un-killable. Why un-killable you say? This tentacle creature can move at Mach 20, so fast he can outrun jets and dodge 1000 of bullet barrages aimed towards him. For whatever reason he plans on destroying the Earth, and for what seems to be no reason at all he wants to teach the class of 3-E. Korosensei past is pretty much a mystery. We get to see glimpses of his past, but not enough through-out the whole series to be satisfying. Usually when a something from his past is hinted, they quickly change the subject. All we know about Korosensei is that he is a tentacle creature willing to go the lengths to help his students, but we don’t know enough about himself. This bugs me, as we need to know more about him. I know there is a season 2 coming out, but seriously, we know almost nothing about him.


Nagisa Shiota is the main protagonist of the series and the narrator as well. Despite his look, by the way he is a he. Looking weak and not academically gifted, he is considered to have the most potential out of all the students in the class, and we find out later why. He plays the role as pretty much an onlooker on all the assassination attempts, watching them to see how they work and going on to explain them and he notes them down, hoping to find weaknesses for Korosensei. I like how this character is developed, because when we see him in action, we see how he gets to know his classmates and his full potential. Yet the show isn’t all about him.


The show is about the class of 3-E. Each episode usually has a scenario focusing on a student in particular. And unfortunately no matter how much of the student is shown, they’re kind of given less as the series progress. Now some of the characters get more screen time than the others, but for the most part, you kind of forget about the character after their initial appearance. It's kind of disappointing, because it seemed they really tried to make an emphasis on the characters especially by their opening listening the name of all the characters, now you’re probably not going to learn all their names, because some of them barely get any screen time. So the show does have a likable cast of characters, there’s just so much more that you can probably care less about. 


Animation and Sound - 7/10, 1/10


The art style is unique from the common anime, however it’s not something we’ve seen before. It has a very similar art style to Attack on Titan, where the characters are highlighted with a thick coat of black strokes. So it’s very obvious when you see that the characters are animated and they are pasted into the separate background. I do like how every character looks unique, they’re all designed differently so it helps you tell them apart. I love when they go into a fantasy imaginary sequence, as I think those were animated quite well, and it really showed epic moments. But that being said, most action scenes are very anti-climactic and we don’t get to see too much of them, and when we do see some of them, it’s nothing special. When we see Korosensei move at Mach 20 Speed, we just basically see duplicates flashing on screen, so it’s really nothing special. But I do like the art style, when they show something normal, but then replace it with an imaginary darker tone, if seen by the other characters.


The soundtrack is quite repetitive as they usually play the same thing over and over, and it’s really nothing special with a few highlights here and there. The action soundtrack is alright, nothing special. But I did enjoy during the last arc, they played this video game esc. soundtrack and it’s really catchy as hell. Now with the opening themes, I loved the opening themes, it was fun to watch and was fun to listen to, having the whole cast sing the song. The dance is cute as well, it’s a really light hearted theme for the show, which fits it well. The ending song is kind of sad though for a show that’s light hearted and filled with comedy. But at the same time it does fill inspirational as well, I just wasn’t sure if really belonged as an ending theme for this show.


Enjoyment - 8/10


When I was watching this show, I knew that they were not going to kill the teacher unless it’s the last episode, so I didn’t watch it for conclusion. I did enjoy watching it for the assassination attempts they tried to pull off, and learning more about that character and how this could be applied to daily life. I really liked how each attempt was different and unique, but at the same time, if you’re not into that, it could get repetitive for you. I especially enjoyed the last arc and development of Nagisa, I just wasn’t satisfied with what we got from Korosensei, we didn’t get enough out of his past. However I did enjoy the story and show itself and I can’t wait for the second season, which has been announced for 2016.


Verdict - 7/10


For the story of Assassination Classroom, I give it a 7, as the overall arching story was predictable with little development. But I did like the individual scenarios they had and also that last arc was really exciting to watch. I did think the concept was pretty cool as well. Although there is quite a few plot holes here and there.


For the animation and sound they both get a 7 from me. For it being the animation is nothing special, but I praise them for having unique looking, distinguishable characters. Some action scenes shined here and there, but there wasn’t too many of them. I enjoyed the soundtrack for what it is, but only a few tracks shined and it was repetitive. The opening songs were fun to listen to, but the ending song sort of felt out of place.


As for the characters I have to give them a 7. Koro-sensei is interesting to a point, but they kept his past in the dark for so long and we haven’t gotten enough out of him. I like the students of the class that got to shine, but there were many of them who were neglected. The cast is a likeable cast though, and they’re all unique as well.


For my own personal enjoyment I give it an 8, because I really enjoyed the concept of the show, and it was fun watching each assassination attempt. I really liked the cast of characters and opening got me pumped up for what’s coming up next. There were some moments when I felt like it was dragging on and it being predictable kind of had me going, how they are going fail this time.


So after round all the scores up I give Assassination Classroom a 7/10. Because if you watch it for the attempts and knowing what the outcome is going to be, it’s a fairy enjoyable watch. It has an interesting concept with a cast of likeable characters. But the nature of the show, many characters got neglected, I can’t give it exactly a higher enough score. The show has moments where it shines, but then sometimes it’s just forgotten and jumps right on forward with the plot. I recommend this anime to comedy lovers, as they might find something special in the mature concept, but with light hearted comedy added towards it. Just be wary there is a second season coming out, so go into it with an open mind that you already know the outcome, so just enjoy each attempt as much as possible.

It's hard for many of us to remember the problems we had as high school students. I mean, sure, there are the usual problems; class drama, gossiping, crushes that went nowhere and so on. But a lot of us tend to forget the frustration that we had with grades, the idea that they're an accurate representation of the quality of a student as well as the fact that our value as individuals have been reduced to mere numbers.
In retrospect, it's kind of amazing how a lot of the things in high school that we learn mean next to nothing when we're elder. I don't recallever needing to do calculus out of high school, and I sure as hell have no use for Physics at any point after high school thus far.


This is what Assassination Classroom ultimately revolves around; it speaks about those 

frustrations that we had as high school students, and acts as a coming of age story of sorts about the characters in the show.


The story isn't believable in the slightest and acts as device to advance its themes and characters, which is very effective. The story instead mainly focuses on the comedic aspects between the students and Koro-sensei, while also balancing out the various character dynamics between not only Koro and the students, but even the students among one another.


This works extremely well, and the character interactions are a great deal of fun to watch. The contrast between the various characters and how they see studying, their love for various things and Koro-sensei is interesting and makes their characterization all the better.


While there isn't as much focus on some of the side characters as I'd hope, meaning that the show is fairly unbalanced in favor of other characters, almost everyone receives development and considering that this show is a success in Japan and that a second season is on the way, it'll only get better from this point onwards.


Another problem is the pacing of the comedy, since a lot of the various jokes don't translate well into anime format and as such makes it rather hit and miss in its presentation. Sure, most of the jokes are still funny and I even found myself laughing very hard at some of them, but the presentation certainly could have been better.


The artwork is smooth and distinct and never drops in quality from episode to episode. The animation quality is pleasant and extremely colorful to look at, though the animation and the way the characters are presented in the opening theme leaves a lot to be desired.


Overall, Assassination Classroom is a very enjoyable show that unfortunately isn't as balanced as it could have been and its comedy being rather inconsistent, especially in the beginning of the show. Those who can get past that will find a likeable cast of characters, some great comedy and a very nostalgia-feeling show (if that's even a thing), so while the show isn't for everyone it certainly is something you can check out if that strikes your fancy.

Essentials to achieving something in life are very closely aligned with a person’s temperament, their dedication, hardwork and support from the environment. Of course, that’s just scraping the general outline since it doesn’t stop at just that as there are countless other factors and qualities needed at specific times to get through nasty situations. However, when we talk about support from the environment, how many of us actually have it? Definitions of competitiveness, teaching and friendship have altered so drastically over time that we find ourselves often straying from the original meaning of these words. While we have a humongous amount of stories which talkabout friendship and competitive scenarios, we barely see any about the weight of teaching in one’s life. Maybe because it becomes boring with all the preaching, is it?


Assassination Classroom shoots that down greatly. All concepts have the potential to be entertaining and deliver messages if they’re executed well and with proper knowledge of the subject in question, but mostly we see the same stretched out ideas being overused (though not necessarily inadequately) in media. However, this series utilizes a unique method to get across the significance of education in a student’s life and most importantly, a good educator to do it well. We fall in Kunugigaoka Middle School, an elite and prestigious institution which will go to extreme lengths to maintain its prominence, so much so that they sort out the weeds among them to a separate E-Class. This class undergoes constant mistreatment from peers and teachers alike for not being able to live by the standards of Kunugigaoka and so they’re given the isolated old campus building, stripped from their facilities available in the main building. Because surely, since they can’t perform well in exams, they must be complete trash, right?


To prove that wrong we have our main character, a yellow octopus-like entity called Koro-sensei, who believes in each of these students and wants to truly develop their abilities… despite being the creature who destroyed 70% of the moon and will do the same with Earth very soon. Right… which is why this class is supposed to assassinate him but damn, isn’t he the best teacher they ever had!


It’s truly entertaining and absorbing at the same time when I think about how well this show handles a dark theme like ‘assassination done by middle school students’ in a lighthearted, humorous and nurturing way. It doesn’t lose sight of the message it wants to convey, whether it’s pressurizing school life or mistreatment of students based on a generalized test of skills. And it does this so well, it’s really compelling. Of course, that doesn’t leave it without flaws since after you catch the drift of the environment portrayed, few incidents become quite predictable and cliché. This doesn’t bring the show too low though since it uses decent pacing to overcome that. A point to consider is that since tastes in comedy are rather varied, it might not appeal to a certain section of people, which is completely fine since it is a subjective topic to begin with.


Since characters tend to be the milestones for a series even after completion, it is to say it’s extremely vital to have a memorable cast of characters. Fittingly, Koro-sensei sticks out the most as a character shrouded in mystery but showing great maturity and wisdom to handle a bunch of middle schoolers appropriately. That doesn’t stop him from fooling around with them though since he becomes a part of E-Class himself rather than being someone who instructs the students from the sidelines. Putting that aside, if you have shots of inferiority complex injected into your bloodstream since childhood (like me), then you might find most characters, especially Nagisa, extremely likeable. The E-Class is full of different types of personalities, who ended up there because of diverse issues in their lives. In such an atmosphere, it’s moderately simple to build up various memorable individuals which Assassination Classroom does accomplish to a certain extent, but not fully. This aspect of the show possesses a lot of potential, which I can only hope to be explored properly with time.


Suitably, the art style is organic and flows well with the usual cheery experience the show plans to deliver. The normal color palette of the show uses bright hues which stand out especially when it comes to the depiction of main characters but the tone changes critically in serious situations and is highly expressive of the impact the show aims for. Designs for the characters stand out well, since not only is it true that they use ‘unusual hair color means important’ trope but take it a little further with aligning the character personalities with said color or overall design. A better gel in could have been crafted between the animated characters and the static backgrounds, since the reference changes in art styles at times but nothing enough to bother the quality the series maintains throughout.


The soundtrack, although not memorable, is moderately apt with the environment. The opening captures the traces of the gleeful journey about to be experienced but doesn’t leave out the subtle hints of the underlying notions. However, the ending takes flight on a lighter, more peaceful note as compared to the opening and the rest of the show but does not fail by itself since it captures the other side of overall picture, which is the memorable and precious childhood of these middle school students. This is also one of the reasons I appreciate this show’s premise, since it does not let the delicate parts of human emotions sink down in the process of tackling heavier themes.


Honestly, I had major doubts about this series and even when I started it out, I wasn’t sure how properly they were going to approach sensitive themes that they planned to. But while watching, some of my critical standpoints faded because the show itself was unexpectedly engrossing and conveyed the message of a teacher’s role in a person’s life through a lens of greater looming thought. As I mentioned before, this might be more appealing to some people than all, but I do think that everyone can somewhat relate at least a little to the environment of the show since school has been quite a large and critical part in all of our lives. I’d recommend this show as taking a dip in a more metaphorical and humorous depiction of school life, which will serve as a unique form of entertainment by itself.

The world is in peril and the enemy just so happens to be your sensei and you have until the end of the school year to assassinate him. That might sound easy enough... right?
Assassination Classroom follows a group of high school students who are tasked in assassinating a tentacle creature who destroyed the moon and that said creature just so happens to be their homeroom teacher. The students later give him the name Kuro-sensei and he is assigned to the E class of an illustrious high school. The students are given training by either a JSPF member or some other military affiliation in Japan, Mr.Karasuma. They are also assigned a language teacher Ms. Irina Jelavić, whom the students called "Professor Bitch". The students not only have to deal with school work but also find a way to eliminate Kuro-sensei before the school year is over. There is also a subplot about the school hierarchy being corrupted and unfair for anyone to succeed.


There are so many characters in this show that I can't even describe all of them and how much I enjoyed each and everyone of them. But the one that steals the entire anime is Kuro-sensei. Kuro-sensei is just the greatest. He is so awesome that I sometimes said throughout this show "I wish I had him as my sensei". Kuro-sensei is the best character on this show in my opinion. Also he is voiced by Sonny Strait in the dun and he was the perfect choice for this character.


Overall Assassination Classroom is one hell of an anime. And if you are an anime only watcher the second season of this show will cover the rest of the manga so watching two seasons of this show is worth it. That aside Assassination Classroom is really entertaining and that is how I generally grade the anime's I watch. I don't like to nitpick unless I'm really going to be critical about it. But, I like to grade shows based entertainment and other factors. And Assassination Classroom is one of those shows that doesn't disappoint and I highly recommend this show if you haven't seen it and giving it an 8/10.

Quite literally my first reaction:
Oh my god! That girl is so cute! I'm really digging the blue-hair! Only, I don't get it, why is she wearing pants and being referred to as "kun"? Wait, it's a boy?!
.
.
.
I didn't say "stop".
Assassination classroom is a rather classical, cliche story with a bizarre setting, that somehow got my attention despite my usual dislike for such overused storylines. The idea is that a terribly fast octopus monster wants to destroy the earth in a year... But for unexplained reasons insists on teaching a class of high-school kids that are trained as assassins to kill him. So he basically trainshis own killers, with the students often attempting to murder him mid-class and on various other occasions. But despite this bizarre (as said) setting, deep down it's just a typical story of a teacher bonding with his students and helping them overcome their problems.\n\n
Aaaaaand... That's it! The plot doesn't really advance apart from the graduation date (and the deadline for killing their monster teacher) drawing ever closer, and pretty much 90% of the episodes are character development fillers that you wouldn't really miss even if they weren't there. So what does draw us to this anime? Well obviously the cute trap, which as the episodes go on the the animators throw more and more to our face (probably caught on on his popularity), but that wouldn't be enough with that limited amount of fanservice, right?\n\n
So I'll just take an educated guess here, and say that the cliche story of a teacher bonding with his students is cliche for a reason and it is well executed here. We've all had that one time in our life when we felt the guidance from our parents was not enough and wanted the help of the people who spent 8 hours of the day watching over us (no, not these ones, the other ones). And when humor is added skillfully to the mix, even an adult can appreciate the notion.

*Minor Spoilers*
For starters, I've actually always wanted to watch this anime, but I was too hesitant to watch it because of that one weird tentacle dude. But now I'm really happy I finally watched this one, because it was a ride.
The story is simple. A giant yellow octopus who's name is "Koro-Sensei" blew up a huge portion of the moon and plans on destroying the earth soon after. Only thing is, he's been assigned to teach a classroom in japan who's notorious for having delinquents and slackers. At the start, most of these kids are prime examples of those things, but Koro Sensei is sogood at being a teacher, that he turns those kids into motivated killers, and even gets them to pass their finals!

Anyways, it may seem like a lot, but it's one of the most interesting anime I've seen in a while.


Sound and art here are respectable. The OP is alright and kinda gets stuck in my head. 


Characters are amazing. My favorites being Koro Sensei, and Karma. Koro Sensei however, is one of the most motivating teachers I've ever seen. I wish he were my teacher! And quite frankly, sometimes he makes me wonder why he wants to blow up the earth, he really seems to love it.


Anyways, the overall for this one is a must watch. It has everything that a great anime needs. Great story, interesting characters, not too much filler, and intense moments. No doubt the second season is probably much more intense. But for what it's worth, this anime is DEFINITELY worth the 10!

Story: As you might have guessed from the title, this anime is about assassinating the 'teacher'. Teacher being an almost un-killable alien octopus thing... Anyways, the story can be really childish and cringey at times, but I found it kinda adorable. It was really amazing how they incorporated both killing and school life so well, the author of this anime managed to somehow tie two polar opposite stuff together really well. Comedy for this show was just ok... it was mainly comebacks by the teacher or student and kind of felt dull at times. 8.0/10.0
Art: The artstyle of the show was not anything exceptional, butit fit the tone of the anime really well, it's a cute with mostly bright colors.  I also liked how even though most of the characters were drawn cutesy (?), they were also sharp. Also to note, the artstyle kind of changed depending the mood of the scene, I thought that was worth noting 8.0/10.0


Sound: Not a big fan of the sound track, its really hyphy and loud.6.0/10.0 


Characters: Even though most characters were kind of one dimensional, the sheer variety of cast made up for it. Due to their being so many characters, half way thorough the anime I was often asking myself 'huh, was he/she really in this class from the start?'. The show really tries to give as much information about every student they can, but it's just wasn't possible in 22 episodes. Personally, I never really felt attached to any character nor did I have any favorites, but I appreciated the work that was put to create them. 7.5/10.0


Enjoyment: One word to describe this anime is fun. This doesn't have the best art, or story, or characters, but what it does have is how well they put it together. It's like one of those surprisingly good sports teams without a star player, but the team with great chemistry. Each element is well supported by each other, and it just makes the show really enjoyable and worthy of watching 9.2/10.0


38.7/50 = 77.4%

This anime was pretty good because it didn't take itself seriously and seemed to revel in its ridiculous concept. The various arcs were fun and were well-paced, keeping me engaged throughout. The recurring villain of "redacted" was ridiculous but it worked because the narrative knew he was ridiculous. He proved to be a pretty fun villain and contributed to an excellent last few episodes. Nagisa and Karma worked well together even if their characters weren't developed that much beyond their base traits.  Some side characters are underutilized like a certain AI machine. The drama involving the principal and his view of the perfect educationwas done well, because it was included sparingly and effectively.The unformity of the characters' motivations hurt it but I didn't mind it much because of how lighthearted the show was.

The japanese voice actors were excellent in their portrayal, specifically for Nagisa, Karna, and Koro-Sensei. English dub voice actors were below average imo.  The animation was simplistic but fluid. Nothing here was great in a writing sense but there's so much fun here that I definitely recommend it.  OP themes are infectiously fun.


Overall Rating: 6.5/10

Enjoyment Level: 8/10

Assassins Classroom. How could I describe this anime in a few sentences?
Assassins Classroom is like the cute but quiet girl who had a crush on you in your formative years but you ignored her because she was a bit boring, only to have her pass you by as she grows into a high-quality catch.
That is Assassins Classroom. Assassins Classroom is the anime that starts off painfully slow but you just start to appreciate it as it winds down to the last episode.
STORY 8/10: 
The story is a typical classroom setting with your token pervert/hentai, class clown, tough guy, nerd(s), popular guy, stud, big-boobed ditz, flat-chestedjealous girl, gender-ambiguous main character, etc and finally a character (Koro Sensei) that simultaneously serves as the major plot device.


There isn't much to write here other than what you probably know already. A classroom is tasked to kill a super-powerful mysterious lifeform before he blows up Earth in a year, and if they actually kill him they get 100 billion yen. The shows premise develops around this desperate desire to kill the teacher.


This class also happens to be the worst class in the school. As such, it is ridiculed by the other classes, although none of the students here are particularly losers. The school they attend just happens to be one of the most prestigious schools in the nation.


ART 10/10:


The art is definitely the best aspect of this show. This show does not spare any effort or expense on looking good. This is truly 201X anime here. There are a lot of school shading, glitch and visual effects. Even the opening scene is rendered lovingly. One can immediately tell that the producers placed a great deal of importance in making sure the anime LOOKS good.


SOUND 8/10: 


Just like the art, the sound is fantastic. I'm not a huge fan of anime music or sound. I normally pass through the intro/outro but Assassins Classroom is definitely better than average.


CHARACTER 6/10:


I thought the character development was admittedly poor overall.Aside from Karma, Nagisa and maybe that green haired girl I didn't really care for any of the other students. This may change in the later seasons but I wish that they developed the other characters more. Perhaps, they don't NEED to and it is actually better they focused on a few notable ones.


I do like Bitch-sensei, Karasuma, and of course love Koro-sensei. I did feel that Karasuma was a bit one dimensional though. He is basically the typical straight man in a comedy show while Bitch-Sensei is admittedly more complicated than she comes off. That is just a testiment to her VA and the character writing.


I found myself being drawn to Koro-sensei as a teacher. They really wrote his role well and accurately portrayed him as a teacher who genuinely cares for his students.


ENJOYMENT 6/10:


This is where I am torn. I can definitely acknowledge that Assassins Classroom is a very good, even great anime that deserves praise. However, it just starts off really slow. I can't put my finger on it, but I think its because it relies on respectable storytelling and substance (good art, music, etc) that there aren't cheap tricks thrown in early to keep the viewer interested. I had to force myself to watch through the first half because while I enjoyed it, I wasn't CAPTIVATED by it like some lower-quality animes.


Maybe I've been trained by terrible Isekei harems that throw some cheap fan service to wake me up, or some super violent horror animes that stress me out. Assassins Classroom does not rely on those things to be good.


OVERALL 8/10:


Assassins Classroom is a very good anime that suffers from slow pacing early on. If one can be patient, they will learn to appreciate it for what it is.

Koro-Sensei. The loveable squid space squid who managed to not only successfully teach the lowest class of the school (Class 3-E) but almost every single character in the anime. Having 'destroyed' 70% of the moon the military try to eliminate him but don't have the power to do so. Kuro-Sensei makes a rather unusual request to teach a class of students with appalling grades who are underachieving. The government surprisingly accepts the demand in which the government then task the students to eliminate him with tools from the army. Kuro-Sensei making this a game give the students 365 days to complete the task knowing fullwell they are trying to kill him. With failure being no option the students try their best to kill their teacher before the given date to receive a huge cash reward. Failure will lead to the end of the world. However with the speed of Mach Twenty the students find it a rather difficult task. Quite an unfair advantage huh? 


Despite the unfair advantage this anime will not fail to bore you. Having being a action packed animation with plenty of emotional moments and giggles along the way. This anime is great at keeping the combination of action, comedy and drama all in one episode. Having known that this character is very op you will eventually get into the animation and how the show works. Stick around long enough to see one heck of an amazing anime. Can be killed or will the world end? 


What makes this show amazing is how Koro-Sensei is very kind and respective despite wanting to destroy the world. Besides this he wants to make the class feel good about themselves and wants them to achieve what they have been told they can't do. 


Without spoiling this anime for you this could be one of the most best animes if not the best anime I've ever seen! 


If you give some of your time to this anime you will have an amazing journey with Class 3-E and feel a mixture of emotions even after the anime has finished. 


"Outstanding" 

10/10 

Tokuwu. 


I hope you guys enjoyed my first review :) Be sure to follow me for more anime reviews!

I'll be placing this {{ALERT: SPOILER INCOMING}} at the start of the spoiler and this {{SPOILER TERMINATED}} at the end of it.
Story - 8
The story is definitely out-of-the-box with the idea of killing your teacher (and not in the frustrated tests way). "Koro-sensei", a name given to the weird creature by Kaede Kayano, is the class teacher of a failure class named "3-E", the E meaning End, and it's students designated to kill their teacher before March 13th. Sounds interesting doesn't it? Read on, it gets better. This teacher not only has extendable tentacles but also a dangerous speed of Mach 20! Despite hisover-powered status, he has several weak points to compensate. During most of the season, the students are studying with their teacher to ace the exams and training with a government agent, Karasuma Tadaomi, to assassinate their mentor alongside. There's a few fanservice moments thrown here and there, as expected of a shounen anime. The story does sometimes go off course but when it's on the tracks, it becomes really fun with a ton of comedy sprinkled on top! The fillers, that I just mentioned, aren't very useless as they contribute to the story in one way or the other. The story proves to be extremely handy to the students of Class E as each one of them come to know that they're very special and talented in one way or the other. Taking all points in mind, I gave it a good ol' 8


Art - 9

Not really much to say about this but as much as I LOVE the animation, scenes can get pretty gross (not too gross, just mildly). Otherwise, all the wavelength (couldn't make a good detailed description without spoiling :P) scenes were pretty well made with showing the facial expression clearly along with the blackness that surrounded it. The action scenes were well detailed and is much praised.


Sound - 10

I really liked both openings regardless of the majority. The openings showed the state of naïveness that the entire class were in with all the happy tunes and of course, the DANCE. Sometimes, OST wouldn't be required but it didn't bother me much because the OSTs were just as good as the openings! Coming to the constant ending song, I REALLY EFFING LOVE IT! It's like it takes all the energy of the episode and just disperses it gently through the air.  


Character - 9

There is a plethora of different personalities gathered in this 47 episode bundle of joy. Every character is different from each other but if not, only 1 or 2 share the same character. Some characters are pretty extreme, for example, Akabane Karma's personality is an extremely troublesome boy's one but there's a really good twist to it that I wont bother to put out, while on the other hand, Terasaka Ryouma is a pretty inflexible guy who sticks to his ideals only. These personalities don't stay around all the time because if they did, character development would be 0 and the rating for Character would be 5. Not only do students have such a variety but so do the teachers. {{ALERT: SPOILER INCOMING}} Irina Jelavich, dubbed as "Ms. Bitch"/"Bitch-sensei" by the entire class, was an arrogant woman who always used seductive tactics to eliminate her targets. At first appearance, she was all of that but then realised she were to settle and adjust with this class. Slowly, she starts to like and care for her students more and more. Karasuma has the same gradual change {{SPOILER TERMINATED}}.


Enjoyment - 8

The comedy scenes in almost every episode lightens the atmosphere and intensity of this assassination classroom of theirs. I would give the Enjoyment sector a 10 but there were several cheesy and cliched parts in this season, as compared to the second one. The fight scenes were really good but then again, the cliched fight explainer was there so that doesn't benefit the score much...if it weren't for the animation and OST! During such scenes, there's always a good OST to go along with it and the animation is, once again, praiseworthy. Not only are the fight scenes great but so are the times when Koro-sensei gives irl life advice. There is always this one perfect OST that is present at that time


Overall: 8

I rated it 8 overall because I think if I compare it with it's way better sequel, giving the first season a 9* would be too biased and felt that I should be a bit more honest with it.

(*= 9 is one the basis of finding the mean; [{8+9+10+9+8}/5= 8.8 and rounds off to 9])

Thank you so much for finishing my review! I'm very glad that you did!

What a clever show.
Its really the one thing that always struck my mind while watching an episode. Bref, we have a teacher who grows the respective skills of his students through his own "assassination" by his own students. If you keep this in mind, you will have a great time with the series and you will understand its uniqueness. Its fun, clever, action packed, mildly psychological, has them feeeeels and is an easy watch. When I think about it, I really think I would of enjoyed the series a tad less if I binged it...1 episode per week was perfect for this type of stuff.


I always loved how the the show constantly tries to stay in a realm of reality, which is super refreshing because it always translates this to improbable problems being solved by improbable solutions and strategies. 


The show surprises you, you also start by thinking that getting to know the full class will not be possible, a bit like something I felt watching Another, but you end up being involved in the character development of practically everyone. I specially found Nagisa interesting as he was haunting but immensely gentle, the creators were absolutely brilliant with him. Gold star! 


Overall the anime stands out, isn't boring, tickles the brain and is definitely worth a watch.

I was very skeptical about this anime. In fact, I started it and then put it on hold before picking it up again, 7 episodes in, about a year later. And you know what? Putting it on hold had been the worst decision I could have made. 
The story is interesting – it's absurd, yes, and at times absolutely ridiculous, but that's the style of story you came for if you saw a yellow octopus in a robe and still decided to watch the show. The humor is pretty good, it had me rolling my eyes and laughing a lot. 
I enjoyed the art style immensely,especially the vibrant colors that you don't get to see that much in anime. Nagisa's eyes were particularly pretty – as was his ridiculous main character hair. 


The music is one of the show's strongest points, from the OP/ED to the actual score. I loved every single piece. 


What I also liked is that every character is a character - and in a classroom of some twenty kids, that's hard to achieve, but the show manages to make most of them very memorable. I also loved the fact that the show brought up some very heavy topics and discussed them, such as gender identity, parental and peer pressure, even mental illness. I loved it. 


And I bawled like a child when it ended.

It's not a bad anime, it works if you want to spend some time when you have nothing else to do, it's funny and the characters are very likely. Koro-sensei is amazing! But if you want an incredible history with awesome plots, it's not for you. The history is just "meh" and nothing really "wow" is going on. I get shocked when I realize that none of the students give a shit about killing a person, it was like "I have to kill my own teacher? ok lol". 
In another hand, it has a really pretty message to pass, and it teaches me a lotwhat how a teacher should be.

Btw, I had a lot of fun watching this, but there are a lot of animes better than this one.

Ansatsu Kyoushitsu
This eccentric and rebellious anime was personally judged by myself too soon to be unworthy of watching. Why is that? I am a fairly realistic guy that enjoys watching more mature anime that provide moral lessons to their stories. Well, it turns out that this anime is far more mature than the visuals of a giant yellow blob monster teaching a classroom of children. Ridiculous, right?
What astonished me the most with this anime is that although yes, it adds a bizarre element that promotes assassinating one of the school staff, but it also reveals insightful moral stories to events that happen. Therefore, not onlydoes the professor teach the students a lesson, but also the viewer as well. 


The children in the story are essentially part of the worst class on campus. The rejects. They failed in school due to their own personal reasons, and therefore were shunned from the remainder of the students on campus by placing their class in a secluded environment far from the main campus. When the children do show up for auditorium gatherings, they are laughed at by their peers and the staff. Sad story, yeah? Not really when you see what the E-class or End class are actually doing on a day-by-day life. 


It's fun, invigorating, and provides the students with a purpose to study hard and really make the best out of life.


Onto the ratings:

Story - 10 - The purpose is incredibly clear-cut. Assassinate the teacher and save the world. This element is so often pursued that it would be hard to give it a lower score. The teacher must die.

Graphics - 8 - Very nice and colourful artwork. Nothing incredibly insane, but overall really nice work. 

Creativity - 10 - I am adding a new category. From ammunition to the assassination attempts and laughs, this story does a great job of being eccentric. 

Soundtrack - 8 - Intense music at the right moments.

Character personas - 7 - A different personality is given to most students, but their backgrounds aren't exactly covered. We don't know why all of them ended up in E-class, and it's always nice to have that relationship with a character built up.

Character voicing - 9 - The monster does an awesome job with exemplifying his part, as well as other characters do really well.


Overall - 9 - Great lessons. Bizarre, but grounded idea. The children must save the world.

Recommended - Absolutely. Season 2 also came out, so I will watch that.

- English Review (Translated version)
I have conflicting feelings with "Ansatsu Kyoushitsu". On the one hand I think it's a really interesting anime, worthy of a good view by every good anime fan. It's funny (VERY funny) and original, apart from having a great technical section, both in the artistic and in the musical part. The point is that I also think that it is a little worse on certain things, or at least falls short of its virtues, in terms of two key elements: storyline/plot structure and characters. And of course, this is important, because it ends up tarnishing the final result and the generalsensations a little.


I think it is indisputable that the strength of "Ansatsu" is his great and peculiar sense of humour. There's not a episode in which there's not a single scene that makes you laugh. And yes, humour is very personal, but it is also an objective quality and in this case it is beyond any doubt. The fun is assured. Luckily it is not just "laughter" and we also find ourselves with a good load of values, principles and ideals, as in any self-respecting shonen, but going a little beyond the simple and overused "companionship " and " the importance of friendship ". They also make an appearance, but they don't just stand there.


As I said, the technical section stands out very much. Visually it is a real delight on screen and the level of animation and drawing is very, very high. Perhaps, to say the least, the weakest point lies in the original design of the characters (with the obvious exception of Koro-sensei), but the overall quality of the art is very good. The musical section is not left behind and the soundtrack is varied, original and fits like a glove in every moment. It features songs that range from more eclectic sounds to epic tones, as well as quieter cuts and cheerful nature. But always bordering on a high level and leaving us some of those melodies that remain in your head. Perhaps one of the best and most complete anime BSO I've ever heard.


As a counterpoint, not everything is perfect in "Ansatsu Kyoushitsu". The supposed main plot is diluted with the passage of the episodes between school tests and the day to day life of the students. This would not be bad (I am a great fan of the "slice of life" genre) if the writers had struck a balance between the two: the "serious" story and the more mundane plots. This has not been the case, and this is something that can be noticed. They give too many expectations to a part of the argument which they then do not develop enough on the basis of that (fictitious) importance. I understand that there is a second season to change this, but well, this is a review of the first and I must judge by what I have seen and not by what I may see later.


Another aspect that could be improved is the characters. Koro-sensei is a great character, original, funny, with nuances. Even the other two teachers (Karasuma and Irina) seem to me interesting in that they are relatively topical in their personalities. The fact is that the students in general seems flat, simple, even irrelevant individually. As a group ("class 3E") I think they are a great idea and a curious concept, but I think that most students are quite insipid on their own. What's more, most of them have a significance of close to zero in the story, they have no depth or influence whatsoever. And this is not because there are a lot of characters. "Shokugeki no Souma" (to name one mainly humorous series) also does this, and yet most of the characters are well-defined, developed and easily recognizable. The fact is that neither the protagonist (who also repels me with this ambiguity about his genre) nor famous characters like Karma (fuck, my preferences definitely have nothing to do with the "generals") seem to me to go beyond the four usual clichés.


To conclude, I would like to mention a few minor aspects, but they are of superlative ingenuity and originality. For example, Koro-sensei's weaknesses, which are taught numbered throughout the episodes. The academy's promotional videos by Kunudon, a few laughs. And a lot of references to popular culture in general and Japanese culture in particular (Nintendo and its 3DS, Naruto...).



- Spanish Review (Original and faithful version)


Tengo sentimientos contrapuestos con "Ansatsu Kyoushitsu". Por una parte pienso que es un anime verdaderamente interesante, merecedor de un visionado por todo buen aficionado que se precie. Es divertida (MUY divertida) y original, aparte de contar con un gran apartado técnico, tanto en la parte artística como en la musical. ¿Muchas virtudes, no? El caso es que también considero que flojea un poco en ciertas cosas, o al menos se queda corta en comparación con sus virtudes, en cuanto a dos elementos clave: trama/estructura argumental y personajes. Y claro, esto es algo a tener en cuenta, porque termina empañando un poco el resultado final y las sensaciones generales.


Creo que es indiscutible que el punto fuerte de "Ansatsu" es su gran y peculiar sentido del humor. No hay ni un solo capítulo en el que no haya alguna escena que haga reír. Y sí, el humor es muy personal, pero también es una cualidad objetiva y en este caso está fuera de toda duda. La diversión está asegurada. Por suerte no es solo "risas" y también nos encontramos un buen cargamento de valores, principios e ideales, como en todo shonen que se precie, pero yendo un poco más allá de los simples y manidos "compañerismo" y "la importancia de la amistad". Que también hacen acto de presencia, pero no se queda solo ahí.


Como decía, el apartado técnico destaca sobremanera. A nivel visual es una auténtica delicia en pantalla y el nivel de la animación y el dibujo es muy, muy alto. Quizá, por comentar algo negativo, el punto más flojo radique en la originalidad de diseño de los personajes (exceptuando, obviamente, a Koro-sensei), pero lo que es la calidad general del arte es muy buena. El apartado musical no se queda atrás y la banda sonora es variada, original y encaja como un guante en cada instante. Cuenta con canciones que se mueven desde sonidos más eclécticos a tonos épicos, al margen de cortes más tranquilos y de naturaleza alegre. Pero siempre rayando a un gran nivel y dejándonos algunas melodías de esas que permanecen en tu cabeza. Quizá una de las mejores y más completas BSO de anime que he oído.


Como contrapunto, no todo es color de rosa en "Ansatsu Kyoushitsu". La supuesta trama principal se diluye con el paso de los capítulos entre pruebas escolares y el día a día del alumnado. Esto no estaría mal (yo mismo soy un gran aficionado al género "slice of life") si los guionistas hubieran conseguido un equilibrio entre ambas cosas: la historia "seria" y las tramas más mundanas. No ha sido así y esto es algo que se nota. Le dan demasiadas expectativas a una parte del argumento que luego no desarrollan lo suficiente en base a esa (ficticia) importancia. Entiendo que hay una segunda temporada donde cambiar esto, pero bueno, esto es una review de la primera y debo juzgar en base a lo que he visto y no en base a lo que quizá pueda ver más adelante.


Otro aspecto mejorable son los personajes. Koro-sensei es un gran personaje, original, divertido, con matices. Incluso los otros dos profesores (Karasuma e Irina) me parecen interesantes dentro de ser relativamente tópicos en sus personalidades. El caso es que el alumnado en general me parece plano, simplón y, si me apuras, irrelevante de forma individual. Como conjunto (clase 3E) me parecen una gran idea y un concepto curioso, pero creo que la mayoría de alumnos por sí mismos son bastante insulsos. Es más, la mayoría tienen una importancia en la historia rozando el cero, no tienen ningún tipo de profundidad ni la suficiente influencia. Y esto no es porque haya una gran cantidad de personajes. En "Shokugeki no Souma" (por nombrar una serie principalmente humorística) también ocurre esto y sin embargo la mayoría de personajes están bien delimitados, desarrollados y resultan fácilmente reconocibles. Es que ni el protagonista (del que además me repele esa ambigüedad al respecto de su género) ni personajes con fama como Karma (joder, definitivamente mis preferencias no tienen nada que ver con las "generales") me parecen que vayan más allá de los cuatro tópicos de siempre.


Para terminar quería mencionar algún que otro aspecto más menor, pero que son de un ingenio y originalidad superlativos. Por ejemplo, los puntos débiles de Koro-sensei, que se van enseñando numerados a lo largo de los capítulos. O los vídeos promocionales de la academia a cargo de Kunudon, unas risas. Y un montón de referencias a la cultura popular friki en general y japonesa en particular (Nintendo y su 3DS, Naruto...).

Story:
The story itself is a huge impact on me. I have never seen such a ridiculous yet interesting and exciting plot! This single aspect makes me watch this series! Nothing more to say! The plot is very well-organised and is both story-oriented and character-oriented.
Art:
The action scenes are great. Nothing more.
Sound:
Okay.
Character:
The characters are quite interesting. I can't see a lot of troupes in Class 3-E, while each character has his own unique character. Different arcs throughout the series not only push the story forward, but also reveal the whole cast bit by bit.
Enjoyment:
11 out of 10!!!
Overall:
!!!

I have one two-word name for you: Koro Sensei. Really, out of all the characters in this show, he makes you want to stick around. Out of all the characters in many anime, to be honest. He is brilliant, complex, witty, flawed, soft, evil, goofy...But believably so. Is he a hero? An anti-hero? Assassination Classroom doesn't spell it out for you so easily. Koro-sensei's character is very fleshed out, and it makes the rest of the show work. Not to say that all other characters are terrible in comparison...
And not to say that the premise of the show itself isn't bad. It's actually quite unique.In the first few episodes it seems kind of simple, immature, non-cerebral even. But as the episodes evolve, you start wondering how these kids really are going to pull off killing this unkillable thing. And if they do figure out a way, if they would even want to. And it's pretty damn funny, especially Koro-Sensei's little quirks. *And* it does get more cerebral if you stick around for the second half of Season 1 and all of Season 2 (This review is for both seasons by the way). I actually recommended this to someone who doesnt usually watch anime, cause I felt like they would appreciate it. That says a lot.

When I first watched this anime a few months back (it took me a while to get though it) I found myself asking "just what the heck is this?" And I felt that way for a long while until about halfway in when the story actually started to come together. 
It was a fun light hearted anime for the most part with lots of jokes and outrages happenings, but I mean lets be real.. What anime doesn't have that sort of idea at least once.. Even when it's not a comedy. 
Once the story began to climax and the real stuff stared to happen that'swhen I found myself the most intrigues as humour is always a good time but the story line is honestly, what usually keeps you hooked. For me, the last few episodes were it's saving grace as I throughly enjoyed it, but you need the patience to get though all the goofy stuff first before you get the the good parts. \n\n
There's some plot holes and unfulfilled things that weren't yet closed off, but I'm reluctant to know that there is a second season so hopefully in that, it clears some things up.

Assassination Classroom is without a doubt my personal favourite anime of all time. While its second season is superior to the first, season one is an absolute enjoyable romp from beginning to end. This one is going to be extensive.
Set in Kunikigokoa Junior High (Spelling probably off) class 3E. A group of struggling students are presented with a brand new teacher at the beginning of their first semester of their final year. This teacher is responsible for having all of the worlds governments on high alert after managing to destroy an entire half of the moon. This teacher has decided he want's to teach thestudents of class 3E in their final year with the final ultimatum. 


Kill me before your graduation, or Earth will suffer the same fate as the moon, if not worse.


Not easy when your teacher is a giant octopus like creature that is immune to traditional gun shots and can travel the speed of Mach 20! Even harder when he is the best teacher you could ask for!


While the title of the show may come across as a more dark and mature anime, this is not the case at all. Assassination Classroom is a colourful, wacky and fun filled show with plenty of humour and silliness. Unlike your traditional Moe style high school show however, Assassination Classroom manages to set itself apart from the rest with a class of roughly 30 students who all get decent screen time across the series as well as plenty to find likeable about all of them, for different reasons. Each episode is rather episodic in nature with the students trying to find different ways to kill off their teacher. While this can become tiresome for some, Assassination Classroom kept me engaged with the different plot threats and revelations that occur throughout the season. One of the main draws is seeing exactly how the students are able to develop and learn from their mistakes. How each student has a weakness and intends to strengthen them as time goes on. The show may seem like all fun and games, but it can take deep and dark turns when it needs to which is in sharp contrast to its regular episodes, but they are dont well and do not feel out of place, instead complimenting the story and helping the characters grow.


What struck me the most about Assassination Classroom was the type of show that is was. Compared to other slice of life, school life shows on the market today, few of them take me back to my school life. Assassination Classroom presents school life in a really down-to-earth way that is really engaging and surprising considering the over-arching plot of the show. More-so in the second season does this become apparent due to the nearing of graduation, presenting that one question that all of us must go through in our lives,


What the hell to do with ourselves once school life is over?


Overall, the story for Assassination Classroom is awesome. The show is not for everyone, no show is. But the story suits the show, surprises in many ways and is very enjoyable to watch. 


The art and sound in the show are simply great. Starting with the art. Each scene within Assassination Classroom is colourful and stands out. Its detailed where it needs to be, its simple where it needs to be. The style of the art is very appealing with a sleek modern anime aesthetic to it. Backgrounds are very nice to look at. One weakness in the art has to do with some character designs. Upon close inspection of the background students on the main campus, a lot of them are re-using assets from the main cast of 30-odd students and slightly remixing them and mixing and matching them. While it is not completely obvious, it does detract a little. 


The sound in Assassination Classroom is very good and fits perfectly. The first OP Seishun Satsubatsuron sung by,  3-nen E-gumi Utatan (Class 3-E Song Unit). The group is comprised of the japanese voice actors for, 

Nagisa Shiota 

Kaede Kayano

Karma Akabane

Hiroto Maehara


If you didnt know the type of show this will be before hand, this opening will definitely tell you. This opening is filled with colourful illustrations of all the characters and their class registration numbers, quick cuts of different scenes upcoming and the all too famous dance off that get the most hardcore Assassination Classroom fans singing along (to the best of their ability lol) and attempting the dance too. 


Opening 2 Jiriki Hongan Revolution also sung by 3-nen E-gumi Utatan (Class 3-E Song Unit) while not being as catchy or iconic as the first opening is still a great OP with an enjoyable song, great visuals and fantastic animation. 


The ending theme Hello, shooting-star by Moumoon is an utterly fantastical piece perfectly befitting the ending animation. Definitely an ending theme to not skip and keep tagged on your music playlist. 


The characters in Assassination Classroom are simply brilliant, the teacher Kuro-Sensei is an absolute JOY to watch whether subbed or dubbed (Will get to that in a bit). Kuro-Sensei is always has that comedic element to him because of his character and the situation he is in. He is able to perform super-human feats and become flustered over the most simple of things. Easily one of the best of the show. 


Main Character Nagisa Shiota is a great protagonist. Nagisa is obviously troubled from episode 1. It is clear that he is a kid and sensible young lad. However he remains rather ambiguous throughout the first season. Instead, Nagisa acts as our guide to the world of Assassination Classroom, he keeps tabs on Kuro-Sensei's weaknesses and provides much needed explanations when required. He is not all of this though, throughout the second half, Nagisa is able to develop into a more fleshed out character with different skills s=to set himself apart from the rest of the class, with his character blossoming in the second season later on. 


The rest of the class are all thoroughly enjoyable. Each new student tends to get an episode centred around them as they enter the class, fleshing them out from the original class mates. While not everyone gets the most screen time or solo episodes, the majority are memorable and most, if not all are likeable or have redeeming qualities, something which is ridiculously difficult to do with a cast of this size.  


Overall. Assassination Classroom is simply a MUST watch. While the second season is better, without the groundwork and foundation layed down by season 1, season 2 wouldn't nearly be as impactful. The show takes many surprising turns throughout its 2 season life and one in the second season which i GUARANTEE you will not see coming. The story is fun and enjoyable and knows when it needs to get serious. This is adventure not to be missed 

9/10

This is a very good anime. When first reading the description I was skeptical about the concept being to far-fetched. A bunch of junior high kids are secretly being rewarded by the government to assassinate a genetically altered life form. 
The further into the show you get the more apparent it is that the show has realistic qualities to it. Each kid in the classroom has some type of problem, thus why they ended up in E class. After watching each episode you can see the characters grow able to achieve the assassination goal. Not only does the lessons the kids learn help them inassassination it helps them in life too.\n\n
 The show is very humorous which adds to more enjoyment of the show.

First thing's first.
I wish that Koro-sensei was my teacher back at school. 
He is what I call an awesome character. 
In general this anime was pretty good. Not amazing and not something that I would, or could watch twice, but still pretty good.
Story: 8
I love this concept! A smiley-octopus-thing responsible for blowing up half the moon? High schoolers who need to kill him before he destroys the earth when he is also their teacher, teaching them how to kill him? Who even thinks of these things, because I applaud  Yūsei Matsui for doing so. This is genius. 
The execution of this however, is adifferent story. Nagisa, the progtag, is a pretty good one, so luckily that doesn't stuff things up. What does, however, are the filler-like episodes. Sometimes I really just wanted the actual story to progress. Knowing what happens in the manga, I would have really loved to see this in the anime. So far, we only get that Korosensi is unkillable. I mean, this had pretty much been established within the first episode alone. I just know there is so much more in store for this anime, so in their second season, they better make it happen!\n\n
Art: 7-ish?\n
S'all right. Wasn't the best of course, and the animation and action scenes can always improve. Even - dare I say it -  Koro-sensei's design can be seen as a pretty lazy. I know, I know, that's probably the appeal, but that's just me being picky. In fact, if Koro-sensei didn't look like that smiley face, he wouldn't really be 'Koro-sensei'.\n\n
Character: 7\n
Out of the entire series I only didn't like one character: that machine who travels by smartphone who I forget the name of because she was kinda just annoying. \n
I did like the main characters, namely Koro-sensei, Nagisa, and side character, Karma, otherwise I don't know the other characters well enough to really care about them. Besides from the fact that they are all young juniors, they do not have much substance. I do understand, however, that there are a lot of them, and going through all their stories (if they had any) wouldn't really work with only 22 episodes. Some characters are quite forgettable (probably because they always fail to kill Koro-sensei) and come off rather bland and cliche. Additionally, we don't really see much character development from probably any one of these characters. I might say except for Karama, because he learns that Koro-sensei is unkillable and cares for all his students, and that maybe he shouldn't be so arrogant. But then again, it's not like he isn't the same sadistic boy that stepped into the school grounds in episode 3. Nagisa remains quiet, clever and 'innocent' and Koro-sensei remains that goofy weird teacher that cares about his students and alas, is still unkillable. I guess that one guy who looks like a bully changes. I forget his name because he isn't that memorable anyway. \n
But in saying all of this, their little character growth isn't a bad thing, because their personalities make up for it anyway.\n\n
Overall: 7\n
I really liked the start of the anime, not so much the end, just because I didn't really like all the characters that much. I know there is heaps of potential in it's second season, and this time we will actually see so much development from these characters. Much excite.\n

Alright, let's go murder some teacher. Oh wait... Do you mean that teacher who pierced through the moon and made that moon in a forever crescent shape? Well then, let me think and prepare for that.
In Assassination Classroom (or Ansatsu Kyoushitsu), class 3-E consists of students who will get the lowest form of education and probably even fail in life. Those students also have no sheer hope in anywhere of their lives as the upper students above their class will always be 'better' than them. However, class 3-E gets a new teacher that will turn their class around this year, and you guess it: it'sKoro-Sensei, the teacher who pierced through that moon.


Story: 8


Just as it was stated in the previous paragraph, Assassination Classroom is your stereotypical classroom, with weapons and tentacles and a hot substitute teacher. NO, IT IS NOT THAT TYPE OF ANIME. Putting that yelling aside, the students in class 3-E has one mission, and that is to kill Koro-Sensei. However, let's just say that the teacher is very smart, fast, and the best teacher that those students have.


Over the course of this anime, students will be able to go through their school year, learning while attempting to kill their teacher. Not much plot is going on (until to the half-way of the anime) in their school year. And yes there will be sports, tests, (summer) vacation, and school trips going on. And the best part of this anime is when the students learn something from the school year which they can apply it to the success of their lives and activities (or another step to try and kill the teacher).


Art and Sound: 9


When watching Assassination Classroom, the arts and sounds REALLY set the stage for what-ever activity or event the students do over the course of their school year. Let it be in a thoughtful attempt to kill Koro-Sensei, or let it be in a dead end pathway where the students has to decide and compromise, or let it be a student getting the spotlight and being bad-ass about it. You get the idea, the arts and sounds really enhance the meaning of the story and characters and especially characters who got a decent amount of screen time in the anime.


The opening and closing of the anime was really good also. The opening gives out a pumping action for viewers to enjoy another episode of it (or to dance with it). Though the opening may ruin the mood when at times the story progresses in a suspenseful way; the opening sets a happy mood in every episode, regardless of where the anime is going. For the closing, it brings a rather calm melody to end an episode. In my opinion, the closing was indeed the best for this anime because it really gives out this vibe of accomplishment and memories the students had went through over the course of the anime. In fact, check it out before you watch it. It's "Hello, shooting-star" by moumoon. (Don't worry, it has very little spoilers).


Character: 8


Though a lot of characters come in over the course of the anime; there isn't much character development happening in the story. Yes there are students who learn from their teachers, but there are way too many students to hear their story fully over the course of 22 episodes. However, it is the many students that makes you feel like you were one of the student. And that is another reason why this anime is great: it puts its viewers into the perspective of either being in one of the student (Nagisa mostly) or being in the scenes of where those students are. It is as if you can emphasize them as the anime progresses.


For the sake of a review, I am not going to introduce all those students or the characters that came into the story.


Koro Sensei: I pretty much explained a lot about it, except Koro-Sensei looks like a yellow octopus (or squid) who dresses like a scholar.
